Convergent evolution is when species from different taxonomical groups independently evolve similar characteristics due to natural selection pressure. Such as bats and birds both evolving wings when their direct ancestors were not closely related or able to fly.

@Godlystriker Us humans may look very different, but we're very closely genetically related. There's basically 2 main reasons why we look different. One is cultural practices of how we dress or manage our bodies and hair. If we were all compared naked and didn't clean ourselves or cut our hair we would look pretty similar. The second main reason is our skin colour. The first humans lived in Africa and had very dark skin, then some people moved north and evolved lighter skin to absorb vitamin D.

The Romans had a saying, "when a Mule foals", like Sal said, It is very rare for hybrids to be fertile, but it does happen. That's why it is important to be aware that a species must produce fertile offspring from generation to generation and not for 1 or 2 generations, like some hybrid groups.

@davelantor I share your love of science, and I hate to be a nit-picker, but genetic drift is but one of the mechanisms of evolution. Speciation can arise from selective breeding, natural selection, gene flow, or genetic drift.

Bulldogs, guided evolution by humans (Selective Breeding).
Tigers, evolution by natural selection (Survival of the fittest).
Mule, Infertile offshoots of closely related species that are barely genetically compatible to breed (WTF).
Speciation, When 2 groups of animals that shared a common ancestor no longer product fertile members by cross breeding due to genetic drift between two groups over long duration of time.
